data.text: Index
Insulin Infusion Pump for Type 1 Diabetes – TA Appendix D: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
This document has been prepared to establish a pathway for commencing and managing children with type 1 diabetes on insulin pump therapy.
Scope

This document is to be used by healthcare professionals of the Paediatric Diabetes Team to consider and initiate insulin pump therapy for children and young people under the age of 19 years with type 1 diabetes.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is
fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix D)
Background
Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion or ‘insulin pump' therapy is recommended as a possible treatment for children 12 years and over with type 1 diabetes mellitus if:
Attempts to reach target haemoglobin A1c(HbA1c) levels with multiple daily injections result in the person having ‘disabling hypoglycaemia', or

HbA1C levels have remained high (8.5% or above) with multiple daily injections ( including using long-acting insulin analogues if appropriate) despite the person and/or their carer carefully trying to manage their diabetes.

Insulin pump therapy is recommended as a possible treatment for children under 12 years with type 1 diabetes mellitus if treatment with multiple daily injections is not practical or is not considered appropriate. Children who use insulin pump therapy should have a trial of multiple daily injections when they are between the age of 12 and  years.

‘Disabling hypoglycaemia' is when hypoglycaemic episodes occur frequently or without warning so that the person is constantly anxious about another episode occurring, which has a negative impact on their quality of life.

Insulin pump therapy may be offered to children and young people by the MDT (Multi-Disciplinary Team) if all the members feel it will help improve glycaemic control, reduce disabling hypoglycaemic episodes and reduce erratic blood sugars provided the family and child /young person is interested in insulin pump therapy.
Aim
To describe the process for being considered and then subsequently being commenced on an insulin pump and the follow up.
The Process
Initial discussions
6.1.1 Requisites for considering insulin pump therapy by MDT:
Families express an interest in insulin pump therapy or the Paediatric Diabetes Multidisciplinary Team feels insulin pump therapy would be ideal for the child or young person;

Families and/or patients are familiar and competent with flexible insulin dosing and carbohydrate counting and have a good understanding of what good glycaemic control is. (Kaufman competency 5 and above) (Appendix B);
Recommend insulin pump self-education material;
Advantages and disadvantages of insulin pump therapy have been discussed with the family and patient, patient and family have realistic expectations of pump therapy;
Team members are assured of family's commitment and motivation to engage with the Paediatric Diabetes Team with regard to getting the best out of insulin pump therapy;
The need to sign a contract on commencement of insulin pump therapy and the commitment to respect the contract is explained to the family.
Assessment of Suitability (Insulin pump assessment) (Refer to Appendix A)
6.2.1 Pump assessment by Paediatric Diabetes Specialist Nurse (PDSN) and Paediatric Diabetes Dietician
Full assessment of the patient's existing knowledge and self-management skills, confirm level above Kaufman Competency scale 5;
Confirm family has read the education material;
Psychological assessment (if possible) if needed;

Dietary assessment including a review of their knowledge of Carbohydrate (CHO) containing foods and ability to use and adjust insulin to CHO ratios. Review food diary to assess portion sizes and insulin carbohydrate ratios, and discuss potential bolus options;
CSII (continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion) therapy education to confirm families understanding;

Explain the terms “basal” (background rate of insulin) and “bolus” (dose patient gives themselves with meals and in accordance with their blood glucose) and the time action profile of rapid acting insulin ;
Demonstrate all pumps and discuss advantages and disadvantages of each in relation to individual patient needs;

The patient decides which insulin pump is best suited to their needs. However the first line pump is the Roche Acu check Insight. In order to obtain access to the insulin pumps a funding form provided by the Clinical Commissioning Group is required to be completed; (Refer to Appendix C - funding form)
Demonstration and opportunity to try different infusion sets (depending on patient's age, parents may try this first);
If patient and carer(s) are committed to CSII therapy, and the Diabetes Team agree, pursue funding and book into pump school if funding approved.
Insulin Pump School

6.3.1 The Insulin Pump School is undertaken by the Paediatric Diabetes Team comprised of Paediatric Diabetes Consultant, Paediatric Diabetes Specialist Nurses and Paediatric Diabetes Dietician. The Diabetes Team manage the Insulin Pump School within the Children's Outpatients Clinic over two days, a week apart. The nursing facility is outsourced by MEHT to an external agency called Provide; however the consultant cover utilises paediatric consultants employed by MEHT. Thus runs separately to the management of Children's Outpatients.
6.3.2 Saline pump start by PDSN and insulin pump company representative.
6.3.3 The insulin pump is loaded on Day 1 with saline so that the patient and/or carer can become familiar with its use.
6.3.4 Education and demonstration on:
Practicalities of wearing the pump;
How to load the battery, to set the date and time;
Cannula insertion and care of the site;
Button pressing ;
How to set up the pump;
Familiarise with the display, menu;
How to give boluses and how to check basal rates;
How to obtain supplies;
Arrange a date for ‘live' pump start (within seven days);
Patient takes pump home to practice button pressing and practical skills.
6.3.5 A live pump is a pump set up with their insulin.
Live Insulin pump start by Paediatric Consultant, PDSN, dietician, Insulin Pump Company representative.
6.3.6 The following points outline the process for further training:
Education about the principle of calculation of basal rates and rationale of various basal rates;
Setting up basal rate, with involvement of family;
Cannula insertion and set change by child/family;
Explanation of temporary basal rates, rationale of changing basal rate adjustment;
Education about advance bolus options;
Education about ‘sick day' management;
How to manage pump failure and how to revert to MDI (multiple daily injections) if necessary;
Discuss lifestyle issues such as alcohol, activity, eating out, travel and driving, where appropriate.
Signing of pump contract by family and professionals;
The patient/family must check their blood glucose 2 hourly for 48 hours and inform the on call MDT member and involve them in the analysis of the results to adjust doses as required;
Follow up
Follow up in nurse led clinic:
1 week after a “live” pump is started the patient needs to attend nurse led clinic to review techniques of cannula change/insertion, glycaemic control and review of basal rates;
Contact by telephone, email or text at least once a week to assess glycaemic control and the patient's coping skills.
Follow up in Consultant led MDT clinic in 4-6 weeks:
Review CSII therapy with patient;
Assess how the patient is coping with the pump;
Review the original goals and agree further targets;
Assess glycaemic control;
Review basal rates and bolus ratios;
Continue education.

Follow up in Consultant led MDT clinic 3 monthly with additional monthly contact with PDSN, if HbA1C <8.5% or follow high HbA1c policy. (Refer to Guideline entitled Children and young peoples Diabetes Service Operational Policy; register number 14013)
Review of contract agreements with the MDT and families at 6 months.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention, using Aseptic Non-Touch Technique (ANTT) when carrying out procedures i.e. administering IV antibiotics.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using high impact intervention guidelines (refer to Saving Lives policy guideline, DoH, 2007) to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy and the Maternity annual audit work plan. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.

The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group report will be reported to the Directorate Governance Meeting on a quarterly basis and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Quality and Safety Committee (PSQC) within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Datix issues along with any complaints are monitored and any learning actioned as appropriate.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Mandatory Training
All Staff attend regular updates on the use of the pumps as well as initially attending “pump school” themselves. All Staff are also required to attend the trust mandatory training programme.
Communication
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff quarterly via email.

Regular memos are posted on the guideline and audit notice boards in each clinical area to notify staff of the latest revised guidelines and how to access guidelines via the intranet or clinical guideline folders
References

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2008). Continuous subcutaneous insulin infusion for the treatment of diabetes mellitus (Technology appraisal guidance TA151) London:NICE Available at: http://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ta151

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2011). Guidance for CSII therapy for children with type 1 diabetes (T1D) London:NICE Available at: http://www.nice.org.uk/media/default/sharedlearning/268_flowchart-pumps.pdf
Kaufman, Francine et al, 2001. Pump Therapy for Children: Weighing the Risks and Benefits Diabetes Spectrum, 14 (2), pp 84-89 Available at: http://spectrum.diabetesjournals.org/content/14/2/84.long
Appendix A
Pathway from Pump Interest to Pump Start
Children with previously diagnosed and established T1DM on multiple daily injection ( MDI)regimen
Consider insulin pump therapy if
MDI regimen inappropriate
Failure to achieve good Hba1c despite best efforts Disabling hypoglycaemia
Consideration by MDT to propose insulin pump therapy to patient and family or
Family expresses an interest in pump therapy
MDT to explain insulin pump therapy to family, includes demonstration of pumps
MDT to provide resources to family regarding information about insulin pump therapy
Explain the pathway of commencing patients on insulin pump therapy and prerequisites of competencies in self-management
If family keen to proceed with  insulin pump therapy
Pump assessment by PDSN, dietician and psychologist
If pump assessment  satisfactory
Consultant to request for pump funding
if approved, proceed to pump start with pump school
Appendix B
Kaufman Competency Scale

table_items.text: Initial information, injections, blood testing, treatment for hypoglycaemia
Blood glucose targets, actions for levels out of target, glucagon, action of different types of insulin, diet and carbohydrate
Determine quantity of carbohydrates in food, use of a plan for carbohydrate intake
How to correct glucose out of target
Decision-making about changes in daily routine adjusting insulin and carbohydrate intake, strategies to prevent hypoglycaemia and DKA
Make base dose adjustments, review blood glucose values to observe overall effects of treatments
Understand hormone pathways and food absorption, know about strategies to reduce complications
Maximized control, basal and bolus therapy
Independence in multiple injections/day or CSII to maximize control, flexibility, and freedom
